Mahek's Reflections

Confidence is a lie. Courage isn’t.

Most people wait until they feel confident. But confidence is usually the result, not the requirement. Courage is what makes you raise your hand, take the risk, or say yes to something uncomfortable. Confidence shows up after. Stop waiting to feel ready. Act before you are.

Belonging isn’t just a DEI checkbox.

For someone like me — an Indian woman raised in the U.S. — belonging is the difference between showing up fully or holding back. It’s whether someone corrects your name, whether your silence is noticed, whether your ideas are remembered. The most inclusive workplaces make sure you’re seen, not just counted.

Not feeling “Indian enough” or “American enough.”

Growing up as a third-culture kid can feel like constantly translating yourself. Too loud here, too quiet there. But we’re not made to fit in — we’re made to stand out. Cultural identity is not about choosing sides, it’s about understanding your story. That’s where confidence lives.

Peer mentorship as real leadership.

Leadership isn’t about hierarchy. It’s about who you make braver. I’ve seen the biggest shifts happen in one-on-one support, quiet confidence, and checking in when no one else does. Peer mentorship changes everything — especially in student teams.

Unlearning “Strong means silent.”

Vulnerability is strength. But we weren’t always taught that. Especially in cultures where strength means endurance, silence, or perfection. I’m learning to replace endurance with curiosity, control with collaboration, and silence with shared space. That’s the kind of strong I want to be.

); } export default Blog;
